Query: Move files and folders recursively on Linux

so_17438493: Moving a file on Linux in C
so_14355279: How can I move all folders in a directory to subdirectories based on their value?
Top-3 Scripts:
ul_527073: #! /bin/bash
for f in aula-??.?.mp4 ; do
    num=${f:5:2}
    mv "$f" Aula"$num"/
done

#! /bin/bash
for f in *.mp4 ; do
    if [[ $f =~ ([0-9][0-9]) ]] ; then
        num=${BASH_REMATCH[1]}
        mv "$f" Aula"$num"/
    else
        echo "Can't extract number form '$f'" >&2
    fi
done

ul_317699: (cd /parent/folder && tail -n +2 | xargs -L 1 mv --) < file

(
  cd /parent/folder || exit
  unset -v IFS
  read skip_header <&3
  ret=0
  while read src dst rest_ignored <&3; do
    mv -- "$src" "$dst" || ret=$?
  done
  exit "$ret"
) 3< file

Top-3 Similar Questions: ul_443125: Move all files with matching prefixes to folder based on a csv list
so_37278705: how to move only files to subdirectory in linux
so_62794681: Shell script to move folders based on file type to its appropriate folder
Top-3 Scripts:
ul_443125: awk 'NR > 1 { print $1, $2 }' list.csv |
while read -r prefix group; do
    find . -type f -name "$prefix*" -exec sh -c '
        group="$1"; shift
        mkdir -p "$group"
        for name do echo mv "$name" "$group"; done' sh "$group" {} +
done

so_37278705: $ mkdir dir/subdir
$ find dir -maxdepth 1 -type f -exec mv {} dir/subdir \;

au_1219009: #!/bin/bash

for i in movies/*; do
    if [[ $i =~ \(([0-9]{4})\) ]]; then
        mkdir -p year/${BASH_REMATCH[1]}
           mv -t year/${BASH_REMATCH[1]} "$i"
    else
        echo "Sort panic!"
    fi
done

so_30307214: cd test

so_22446270: cd /home/user/Desktop/
find . -type d -print0 | xargs -0 -I'{}' echo mkdir -p '/home/user/Documents/{}'
find . -type f -print0 | xargs -0 -I'{}' echo mv '{}' '/home/user/Documents/{}'
